content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting idea. A clear statement, well-defined goal. 
Can be solved in under 5 minutes.  Extra credit for the name choice

Compared to other puzzle, default code does not include the output line.
Otherwize than that, it is good although not an easy one for "size of code"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Uses either tree concepts or recurring function

Thanks.

Inspired by a pstree reimplementation based on the (pid, ppid) output of ps.

The algorithm is not the optimal, but for me, it is easier to understand this recursive backward-on-a-tree-branch checking for each node.

Done: default code includes output line.

Thanks.

Thanks for the approval.

Using mutable as default value should be avoided (descendants=[]).
Here, the empty list created only once and at the next call it may not be empty anymore.
If you would leave out the descendants parameter in the recursive call, the function would do the same.
if you would call dfs(s) twice, it would return 2 * the previous result.
I did not understand. I just traverse all the nodes and populate the list. It does not involve backtracking so I want the list modified in each call.

def fn(x=[]):
    x += [9]
    return x

y = fn()
print(y)
[9]

y += [1]

print(fn())
[9, 1, 9]

print(y)
[9, 1, 9]

That's why mutable should not be used as default value, even your example outputs the good result.

This is better:
- def dfs(mother, descendants=[]):
+ def dfs(mother, descendants):
...
- k = sorted(dfs(s))
+ k = sorted(dfs(s, []))
Thanks for the explanation. Yes you are right. Good to know that.
